channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Crisis Abates in Russia but Questions Remain Over Putin’s Authority
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner mercenary group who led an uprising against the Russian military leadership, agreed to end hostilities and head to Belarus. Residents of a southwestern Russian city cheered Wagner’s forces as they left.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Prigozhin, Putin’s Beast, Turned on Him Before Apparently Reversing Course
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the paramilitary Wagner Group, has been driven to fury by a mismanaged war in Ukraine. He turned on his creator, before apparently reversing course.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recruitment billboards for Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s Wagner paramilitary group have multiplied in Moscow and other Russian cities in the past few months.

item.title: Guatemala Election: What to Know
item.description: The election in the Central American nation is marked by the exclusion of top candidates and calls to crack down on violent crime.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters along La Reforma Avenue last week in Guatemala City.

item.title: Arnon Milchan Testifies in Benjamin Netanyahu’s Corruption Trial
item.description: Arnon Milchan, a movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, is a key witness. He gave the Netanyahus gifts, he said, sometimes at their request.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Arnon Milchan in London in 2018. He is testifying from Brighton, England, via a video conference link to the Jerusalem District Court.

item.title: Taiwan Faces a #MeToo Wave, Set Off by a Netflix Hit
item.description: A torrent of sexual harassment accusations has prompted questions about the state of women’s rights on an island democracy that has long been one of Asia’s most progressive places.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien

item.title: Greek Youths, Shaped by Debt Crisis, Plan to Vote for Stability
item.description: Many children of Greece’s traumatic years of economic collapse have opted for pragmatism over radicalism and say they will back a conservative on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syntagma Square on Tuesday in Athens. In many parts of Greece, youthful radicalism has given way to unexpected pragmatism that is visible in pre-election polls.

item.title: Short-Lived Mutiny in Russia Sheds Light on Putin’s Hold on Power
item.description: The armed standoff on the road to Moscow, brief as it was, represented the most dramatic struggle for power in Russia in decades.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin addressed Russia on Saturday amid an attempted mutiny that American officials saw as evidence of his eroding position.

item.title: Rebel Wagner Forces, Threatening Moscow, Abruptly Stand Down
item.description: The mercenary group had seized the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, the center of Moscow’s military operations in Ukraine, posing a grave threat to President Vladimir Putin’s government.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Fighters with the Wagner private mercenary group deployed on a street near the headquarters of the Southern Military District on Saturday in the city of Rostov-on-Don, Russia.

item.title: China’s Extreme Floods and Heat Ravage Farms and Kill Animals
item.description: China’s leader has made it a national priority to ensure the country can feed its large population. But weather shocks have disrupted wheat harvests and threatened pig and fish farming.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:description: Villages in the southern region of Guangxi affected by rainstorms this month. Chinese officials have warned about the growing threat of extreme weather.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Wants Tourists. It Didn’t Expect Christians.
item.description: In a fluid new age for the conservative Islamic kingdom, evangelicals have become some of its most enthusiastic visitors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Iman Al-Dabbagh
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times

item.title: How Do Kwon, a Crypto Fugitive, Upended the Politics of Montenegro
item.description: Only days before an election in Montenegro, a letter from Do Kwon, the fugitive founder of the Luna digital coin, claimed that crypto “friends” had provided campaign funding to a leading candidate.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Do Kwon, the fugitive head of a bankrupt crypto business, in custody in March in Podgorica, Montenegro.

item.title: Health Benefits for U.S. Veterans From Pacific Nations Get Step Closer
item.description: Citizens of three Pacific Island nations, eligible to serve in the U.S. military, have faced a Catch-22 in gaining access to certain benefits. That may change soon.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Akasha Rabut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A veteran from the Marshall Islands at a Department of Veterans Affairs hospital in Hawaii in May. U.S. veterans from there and from Palau and the Federated States of Micronesia could be closer to free health care.

item.title: Polar Prince, Ship That Launched Titan Submersible, Returns to Newfoundland
item.description: Investigators boarded the Polar Prince, which docked at the Atlantic headquarters of the Canadian Coast Guard, looking for answers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Polar Prince, the ship that launched the Titan submersible, returned to its home port in Newfoundland, Canada, on Saturday, where it was boarded by investigators from the Transportation Safety Board of Canada.

item.title: Crisis Abated
item.description: Vladimir Putin averted a threat that came closer than anything else has to endangering his hold on power.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Wagner fighters leave Rostov-on-Don, Russia, yesterday.

item.title: Bangladesh Offers a Glimpse of the Water Crises of Tomorrow
item.description: Bangladesh, a river delta nation, is on the front line of climate change. Its coping strategies could offer lessons for the wider world.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Fabeha Monir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monika Kirtanya, Mr. Kirtanya’s wife, with fresh vegetables from the garden.

item.title: U.S. Knew Prigozhin Was Preparing to Take Military Action Against Russia
item.description: The information was considered both solid and alarming because of the possibility that a major nuclear-armed rival of the United States could descend into chaos.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Prigozhin Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yevgeny Prigozhin in a screen capture from his video address from Rostov-on-Don, Russia, on Saturday after it was captured by his mercenary troops.

item.title: As Putin’s Partner, Prigozhin Was Always Willing to Do the Dirty Work
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the mercenary leader of the Wagner Group, had earned the trust of Vladimir V. Putin. Then he staged a mutiny that rattled the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Kyle Crichton
item.media:description: Wagner fighters in the center of Rostov-on-Don, Russia, on Saturday.

item.title: Timeline: What Led to the Standoff Between Russia and Prigozhin
item.description: The leader of the Wagner mercenary group had kept a low profile for years, only acknowledging his force’s existence in September of last year.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A frame of a video posted on Saturday on Telegram shows Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Wagner leader, speaking with two Russian military officials in a Russian military headquarters in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don.

item.title: Map: Tracking Wagner Military Convoys in Russia
item.description: Wagner’s leader announced that his troops marching on Moscow would “turn around.”

item.title: Arnon Milchan, the Mogul Testifying Against Israel’s Netanyahu
item.description: Arnon Milchan, the movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of Benjamin Netanyahu, is about to testify at the Israeli prime minister’s corruption trial.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A personal relationship between Mr. Milchan, left, and Mr. Netanyahu dated to 1999, and the gift-giving lasted from 2011 to 2016, according to the Israeli indictment.

item.title: Putin Embraced Turmoil. Now It Is Rattling His Leadership.
item.description: For more than two decades, the system helped President Vladimir V. Putin secure his unrivaled authority, ensuring that he personally held the keys to wealth and influence in modern Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, greeting veteran soldiers as he attended a wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the Alexandrovsky Garden near the Kremlin wall in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Crisis in Russia
item.description: A Russian mercenary leader claimed he controls a military headquarters in southern Russia, and Vladimir Putin vowed to take action.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Wagner fighters in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, today.

item.title: Killing of Sikh Leader Raises Fears in British Columbia
item.description: Members of the Sikh community in Surrey believe that Hardeep Singh Nijjar, the president of a local temple, was killed because of his political views.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Sikh community at the Vaisakhi parade in Surrey, British Columbia, in April.

item.title: Watch Rare Burmese Peacock Turtles Hatching
item.description: Local conservationists at Indawgyi Lake captured the first known videos of rare Burmese peacock turtles hatching.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa

item.title: Sierra Leone’s Election: What to Know and Latest News
item.description: In Saturday’s vote, President Julius Maada Bio is seeking a second five-year term to pursue an ambitious if unfulfilled education initiative, while the country is facing a crippling economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Campaign posters in Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone. The country is holding a presidential election on Saturday.

item.title: What’s Happening in Russia? What We Know About Wagner’s Military Revolt
item.description: A powerful mercenary chief sent his forces on the move against the Russian military establishment, raising tensions in the country to a level not seen in decades.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney and Mike Ives
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A fighter with the Wagner private mercenary group patrolling near the headquarters of the southern military district in Rostov-on-Don on Saturday.

item.title: Wagner Chief Prigozhin Appears in Videos at A Russian Military Headquarters
item.description: The head of the mercenary group claimed to have control of parts of the complex in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don.
item.dc:creator: Dmitriy Khavin, Sarah Kerr, Riley Mellen and Muyi Xiao

item.title: Debris From Russian Missile Kills Two in Kyiv Apartment Building
item.description: The capital came under attack as anxiety grew in Russia over a confrontation between Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Who Is Prigozhin, the Wagner Leader Russia Accused of Mounting a Coup?
item.description: Mr. Prigozhin has risen from a businessman known as President Vladimir V. Putin’s “chef” to a symbol of wartime Russia, controlling a private army operating from Ukraine to Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ben Shpigel and Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, center, founder of the mercenary military group Wagner, attending the funeral of a Russian military blogger in Moscow, in April.

item.title: Google News Blocked in Russia as Feud With Prigozhin Intensifies
item.description: At least five telecommunications companies have blocked the service, which aggregates news from various sources, according to an analysis from NetBlocks, an internet observatory.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:description: Mikhail Oseyevsky, president of Rostelecom, meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow earlier this month.

item.title: Titan Submersible and Greek Migrant Crisis: Tragedies Reveal Inequities in World Attention
item.description: Many see harsh realities about class and ethnicity in the attention paid to the Titan submersible and the halfhearted attempts to aid a ship before it sank, killing hundreds of migrants. But there are other factors.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: An undated photograph released by OceanGate Expeditions of the Titan submersible.

item.title: The Dark Incentives That Led to a Refugee Tragedy
item.description: To those who see refugees as a burden or threat, border security is a zero-sum game that can be “won” by keeping potential asylum seekers out or by forcing them into other countries.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Family members of missing victims waiting to donate DNA samples at a hospital in Khuiratta in the Pakistani-administered part of Kashmir.

item.title: A long-running feud has broken into open confrontation. Here’s the latest.
item.description: The claims from Yevgeny V. Prigozhin including a veiled threat of an uprising against Russia, prompted the F.S.B. to open a criminal investigation.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Armored vehicles on a street of the southern city of Rostov-on-Don, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: Submersible Expert Raised Safety Concerns After 2019 Trip on Titan Sub
item.description: After hearing a loud cracking sound during the dive, the expert, Karl Stanley, emailed OceanGate’s C.E.O., Stockton Rush, to urge him to hold off on future trips.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Debris from the Titan was found on Thursday, ending a four-day, multinational search for the 22-foot watercraft.

item.title: Modi’s Visits Abroad Help to Build His Image in India
item.description: For an audience in India, the prime minister is linking his diplomatic reception abroad, and himself, to the country’s growing importance on the world stage.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Biden greeting crowds on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Hosts Artists in Sistine Chapel, Even Some Who Attracted Controversy
item.description: The event was part of a broader effort to engage with artists as the Roman Catholic Church did in the past. Pope Francis also urged them to pursue social justice through their work.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A photo released by the Vatican on Friday showed Pope Francis speaking to artists at a gathering that he hosted in the Sistine Chapel.

item.title: Democracy and Reality
item.description: We are covering Narendra Modi’s visit to the U.S., the implosion of the missing submersible and the N.B.A. draft.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Jill Biden, Narendra Modi and President Biden at the White House last night.

item.title: 88 Temples, 750 Miles, Untold Gifts: Japan’s Shikoku Pilgrimage
item.description: A famed route on the smallest of Japan’s four main islands offers breathtaking views and an array of lessons on history, culture and generosity.
item.dc:creator: Marta Giaccone

item.title: As Lord Mayor, a 22-Year-Old Vaulted From Public Housing Into London’s Elite
item.description: Hamza Taouzzale became the first Muslim and youngest ever Lord Mayor of Westminster, a ceremonial post that outranks many of the capital’s most powerful and privileged.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamza Taouzzale, center right, with a friend on the street near his home in London.

item.title: A War-Themed Restaurant in Ukraine Finds New Resonance
item.description: A restaurant that celebrates Ukraine’s struggles in earlier wars is finding a second life in this one.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kryivka restaurant in Lviv is a themed restaurant that evokes Ukraine’s armed fight for independence against Soviet Russia and Nazi Germany during World War II.

item.title: Washington Spirit’s Michele Kang Wants to Take Women’s Soccer Clubs Global
item.description: With the rapid rise of women’s soccer, Y. Michele Kang, the owner of the Washington Spirit, is in the vanguard of transforming ownership and management worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Y. Michele Kang, the owner of the Washington Spirit at Audi Field in Washington, D.C. She aims to boost women’s soccer to a new level with her creation of an international network of soccer clubs.

item.title: How NATO Blends Aircraft From 25 Nations
item.description: The alliance’s “Air Defender” exercises, the largest in its history, have focused on communications, particularly on synchronizing multiple encryption systems.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Lt. Brad Lynch explaining details of an A-10 Thunderbolt during the NATO Air Defender exercises in Lechfeld, Germany, on June 9.

item.title: With a Hand From the U.S. Military, Aid Finally Reaches a Syrian Camp
item.description: “I saw people eating plants that are usually only used to feed animals,” said one resident of a camp for displaced Syrians that sits in the shadow of an American military base but has been cut off from aid for years.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Refugees outside a United Nations-operated clinic near the Rukban camp in Syria in 2017. The organization’s aid shipments last reached the camp in 2019.

item.title: On Aung San Suu Kyi’s Birthday, Flowers, Then Arrests
item.description: People across Myanmar wore flowers on Monday to show support for the jailed civilian leader. Since then, the ruling military has been rounding them up.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Yangon Revolution Force, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A banner addressed to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s imprisoned former leader, on a bridge in the city of Yangon on Monday, her 78th birthday.

item.title: Canada’s Online News Act Targets Facebook and Google
item.description: A new Canadian law will require technology companies to license news content. Facebook’s owner said it would drop news from the platform.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Pavlo Gonchar/SOPA Images, via LightRocket, via Getty Images

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The discovery of wreckage from the Titan submersible.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Experts had long warned of possible “catastrophic” problems with the submersible’s design.

item.title: Tipping Gets ‘More in Your Face,’ and Not Everyone Likes It
item.description: Tipping is not unheard-of in Australia, but an increasing number of apps and payment platforms are actively asking for an extra dollar, or five, on bills.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tipping “seems to be becoming something that is more often being requested,” said Tony Green, the chief executive of Australian Foodservice Advocacy Body.

item.title: Shahzada Dawood, Wealthy Executive, Died With Son, Suleman, on Submersible
item.description: Mr. Dawood, a British Pakistani businessman, was the vice chairman of Engro Corporation, a conglomerate owned by one of the richest families in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Dawood Hercules Corporation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shahzada Dawood in an undated photo. The businessman, environmentalist and adventurer died aboard the Titan submersible.

item.title: Mexico’s Supreme Court Rejects AMLO-Backed Election Changes
item.description: The ruling from the country’s top court came as President Andrés Manuel López Obrador ramps up his attacks on the judicial system.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador earlier this month.

item.title: Missiles Strike Russian-Held Bridge Far Behind Ukraine Front Line
item.description: The attack damaged a bridge in the Russian-occupied Crimean Peninsula that Moscow uses to resupply its forces in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian-installed leader of the Kherson region purported to show damage to the bridge connecting to the Crimean Peninsula.

item.title: Hamish Harding, Explorer Who Knew No Bounds, Dies at 58 During Titanic Dive
item.description: An aviation tycoon who pushed the limits, he went to the depths of the ocean and the blackness of space before his fateful dive to the Titanic on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Hamish Harding, a British adventurer, probed the depths of the earth and the heights of the heavens.

item.title: Turkey Raises Interest Rates as Erdogan Aims to Tame Inflation
item.description: In his choices of top officials, and with a leap in interest rates, Mr. Erdogan aims to tame inflation and defuse a looming economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turkey’s central bank hiked interest rates sharply on Thursday, indicating that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is embracing orthodox economic policies in an effort to throttle soaring inflation.

item.title: Protecting Marine Life Also Helps People Nearby, Study Says
item.description: A study of marine-protected areas off the Central American coast found that people living close to these areas had better food security and greater household wealth.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Irlaya, a fishing village on Honduras’s Caribbean coast.

item.title: Israeli-Palestinian Violence Is Spiraling in the Occupied West Bank
item.description: The Palestinian Authority is absent from the hotbeds of militancy while Israeli forces have failed to prevent violent reprisal attacks by Jewish extremists.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Smoke rising above the West Bank city of Jenin on Monday during fighting between Israeli forces and Palestinian gunmen.

item.title: The Politics of Class
item.description: We’re covering the class inversion in American politics, severe weather in Texas and the Indian prime minister’s visit to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in the Bronx, where President Trump improved his margin from 2016 to 2020.

item.title: Paris Fire and Explosion Leave 1 Missing and 6 Critically Hurt
item.description: The origin of the explosion, which gutted a building in the Fifth Arrondissement and injured about 40 people, is still unclear.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Global Climate Economy Conference Begins in Paris
item.description: Hundreds of representatives from about 80 countries are gathering in Paris to talk about rebuilding a monetary system many say is ill-suited to a changing planet.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Climate activists demonstrating before the opening of the conference in Paris.

item.title: Korean Youth Hostel Once a Site of Interrogation and Torture
item.description: A building where South Korean dissidents were interrogated and tortured by a powerful government agency is now home to a popular youth hostel.
item.dc:creator: Lauretta Charlton
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Seoul Youth Hostel in Namsan used to be the headquarters of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, where pro-democracy protesters were brought for interrogation during South Korea’s postwar authoritarian years.
